item.title: 27: React Today and Tomorrow with the React Core Team
item.description: The React core team sits down with Michael Jackson to discuss React today and tomorrow. They talk Concurrent Mode, Suspense, Hooks, the new profiler tab, scheduling in the browser, React Fire, React Fusion, becoming more framework-y, appearing less JavaScript-y, and why you shouldn‚Äôt worry about the second argument of useEffect.
item.content:encoded:
The React core team sits down with Michael Jackson to discuss React today and tomorrow. They talk Concurrent Mode, Suspense, Hooks, the new profiler tab, scheduling in the browser, React Fire, React Fusion, becoming more framework-y, appearing less JavaScript-y, and why you shouldn‚Äôt worry about the second argument of useEffect.

Featuring

  • Sebastian Markb√•ge ‚Äî Twitter, Github, Medium
  • Sophie Alpert ‚Äî Twitter, Github, Website
  • Dan Abramov ‚Äî Twitter, Github, Medium
  • Andrew Clark ‚Äî Twitter, Github
  • Brian Vaughn ‚Äî Twitter, Github, Website
  • Michael Jackson ‚Äî Twitter, Github, Website

Notes & Links

  • React v16.6.0: lazy, memo and contextType
  • React Hooks
  • React Dev Tools
  • React Fire
  • Prepack

item.title: 26: Chill Out and Listen with Brad Frost
item.description: Brad Frost is the author of Atomic Design, renowned speaker, and consulting designer. Chantastic asks him about his recent experience learning React and the difficulty he found entering the realm of React. They talk about team communication, developing portable solutions, organizational therapy through design, and creating a virtuous cycle between product, design, development, and systems creating. They address the challenges of learning UI design in an industry being consumed by JavaScript, the importance of listening and the value of finding nuance in communication.
item.content:encoded:
Brad Frost is the author of Atomic Design, renowned speaker, and consulting designer. Chantastic asks him about his recent experience learning React and the difficulty he found entering the realm of React. They talk about team communication, developing portable solutions, organizational therapy through design, and creating a virtuous cycle between product, design, development, and systems creating. They address the challenges of learning UI design in an industry being consumed by JavaScript, the importance of listening and the value of finding nuance in communication.

Featuring

  • Brad Frost ‚Äî Twitter, Github, Website
  • Michael Chan ‚Äî Twitter, Github, Website

Notes & Links

  • Atomic Design ‚Äî A methodology for creating design systems.
  • Pattern Lab ‚Äî¬†Build thoughtful, pattern-driven user interfaces using atomic design principles.
  • Creative exhaust, the power of being open by default: Brad Frost at TEDxGrandviewAve
  • my struggle to learn react ‚Äî Brad's thoughts on the difficulty of learning React
  • i dunno ‚Äî Brad's thoughts on getting impaled for detailing his struggle to learn React
  • dumb react ‚Äî A collection of dumb React components that are used to stitch together a website screen

item.title: 25: Make Brilliant Messes with Diana Mounter and Emily Plummer
item.description: Diana and Emily create design systems at Github. Chantastic asks them about the story of design at Github, what role React will play in future systems, and what community tools that make their job easier. They talk Rails, Lerna, monorepos, Figma, component APIs, and the importance of supporting your design system by supporting designers and engineers. It‚Äôs a great discussion for everyone looking to improve processes in a legacy application.
item.content:encoded:
Diana and Emily create design systems at Github. Chantastic asks them about the story of design at Github, what role React will play in future systems, and what community tools that make their job easier. They talk Rails, Lerna, monorepos, Figma, component APIs, and the importance of supporting your design system by supporting designers and engineers. It‚Äôs a great discussion for everyone looking to improve processes in a legacy application.

Featuring

  • Diana Mounter ‚Äî Twitter, Github, Website
  • Emily Plummer ‚Äî Twitter, Github
  • Michael Chan ‚Äî Twitter, Github, Website

Notes & Links

  • Jon Rohan ‚Äî Systems Designer at Github
  • Jina Anne ‚Äî Design Systems OG, DSC organizer @sf_dsc, @NYC_DSC
  • NYCDSC ‚Äî Design Systems Coalition meetup in New York
  • Donut.js ‚Äî Emily's web development meetup in Portland. Organized by Matt McVicker
  • Primer Style Guide ‚Äî Resources, tooling, and design guidelines for building websites with Primer, GitHub's front-end framework
  • Minimal API Surface Area ‚Äî¬†JSConf EU talk by Sebastian Markb√•ge
  • BEM naming methodology ‚Äî¬†Conventions for extendable and reusable interface components
  • Design systems at Github ‚Äî A Medium piece by Diana on everything design systems at Github. It goes into the tech and support roles of the Design Systems team
  • Lerna ‚Äî üêâ A tool for managing JavaScript projects with multiple packages
  • Using Figma designs to build the Octicons icon library ‚Äî¬†An article by Jon Rohan on their new icon system
  • styled-system ‚Äî ‚ú® Responsive, theme-based style props for building design systems with React
  • emotion ‚Äî Performant and flexible CSS-in-JS
  • Probot ‚Äî GitHub Apps to automate and improve your workflow
  • Primer Component ‚Äî Github's React component driven style system
  • Next.js ‚Äî A React framework
  • MDX ‚Äî Markdown for the component era.
  • mdx-docs ‚Äî üìù Document and develop React components with MDX and Next.js
  • Andrew Clark: React Suspense ‚Äî A powerful new set of primitives for addressing longstanding problems in UI development
  • @githubprimer ‚Äî The design system that powers GitHub. Maintained by @broccolini, @jonrohan, @shawnbot, & @emplums

item.title: 24: Chase Whimsy with Burke Holland
item.description: Chantastic asks Burke Holland about Five Things, VS Code can do that?!, and what brought him to computers. They discuss Windows 98 UI, React at Microsoft, the gateway drug to TypeScript, React Food Truck, and how how he discovered the identity of horse_js.
item.content:encoded:
Chantastic asks Burke Holland about Five Things, VS Code can do that?!, and what brought him to computers. They discuss Windows 98 UI, React at Microsoft, the gateway drug to TypeScript, React Food Truck, and how how he discovered the identity of horse_js.

Featuring

  • Burke Holland ‚Äî Twitter, Medium
  • Michael Chan ‚Äî Twitter, Github, Website

Notes & Links

  • Five Things ‚Äî a show about JavaScript, Node and all things web.
  • VS Code can do that?! ‚Äî All the best things about Visual Studio Code that nobody ever bothered to tell you.
  • Microsoft Office rewrite in React.js nears completion
  • Microsoft Azure ‚Äî Turn your ideas into solutions faster using a trusted cloud that is designed for you.
  • React Food Truck for VS Code ‚Äî A collection of curated extensions for discerning React developers.
  • DISCOVERING THE TRUE IDENTITY OF @HORSE_JS USING MACHINE LEARNING ‚Äî Burke and Jasmine's JSConfUS 2018 talk.
  • Vue.js ‚Äî¬†A progressive, incrementally-adoptable JavaScript framework for building UI on the web.
  • TypeScript ‚Äî JavaScript that scales.
  • Cycle.js ‚Äî A functional and reactive JavaScript framework for predictable code.
  • Jasmine Greenway
  • John Papa

item.title: 23: Ditch Authority with Sunil Pai
item.description: Chantastic talks with Sunil Pai about Facebook, Oculus, and what the future holds for the JavaScript community. They discuss Sunil‚Äôs early adventures in programming, why firebug changed everything, how he came to mad dogs models, the ways we protect ourselves from criticism, being ‚Äúevil by accident‚Äù, and becoming The CSS Guy for the rest of eternity.
item.content:encoded:
Chantastic talks with Sunil Pai about Facebook, Oculus, and what the future holds for the JavaScript community. They discuss Sunil‚Äôs early adventures in programming, the power of a great manager, why firebug changed everything, why he scowls at models, the ways we protect ourselves from criticism, being ‚Äúevil by accident‚Äù, and becoming The CSS Guy for the rest of eternity.

item.title: 22: Promise Accessibility with Ryan Florence
item.description: Chantastic talks with Ryan Florence about Reach UI and why accessibility is important for everyone. They discuss the balance of physical and mental activity, Ryan‚Äôs foray into programming and entrepreneurship, the inspiration behind his accessibility-first component library, and why none of us are really full-stack developers.
item.content:encoded:
Chantastic talks with Ryan Florence about Reach UI and why accessibility is important for everyone. They discuss the balance of physical and mental activity, Ryan‚Äôs foray into programming and entrepreneurship, the inspiration behind his accessibility-first component library, and why none of us are really full-stack developers.

Featuring

  • Ryan Florence ‚Äî Twitter, Github, Website
  • Michael Chan ‚Äî Twitter, Github, Website

Notes & Links

  • reach.tech
  • Reach UI ‚Äî¬†The accessible foundation of your React-based design system.
  • Voice Over ‚Äî The screen Reader built into MacOS.
  • NVDA ‚Äî¬†The screen reader typically paired with FireFox.
  • JAWS The screen reader typically paired with IE11 or Edge.
  • React Spring ‚Äî Helping react-motion and animated to become best friends
  • Gatsby v2 Announcement
  • MDX ‚Äî A format that lets you seamlessly use JSX in your Markdown documents.
  • Tweet from Zack ‚Äî "As someone who recently learned they're going blind, thank you. I never realized quite how important this work is until now and I regret not putting more effort into it in previous projects." ‚Äî Zack
  • Brent Jackson

item.title: 21: Delete Your Components with Kent C. Dodds
item.description: Chantastic talks with Kent C Dodds about his adventures in React development and why we should be optimizing code for delete-ability. They discuss React Rally, managing your career, taming your ego, keeping healthy and happy on Twitter, tools for composing components well and when to use them, and what‚Äôs next for React.

item.title: 20: Foster Vibrant and Inclusive Communities with Devon Lindsey
item.description: Chantastic talks with Devon about her adventures in web development and why she organizes the ReactJS San Francisco Bay Area meetup. They discuss how to foster vibrant and inclusive communities, why React Rally is so special, and what it means that Apple is sponsoring a React conference.

item.title: 19: Supporting Open Source with Michael Jackson
item.description: Chantastic talks with Michael about his journey into open source and how he's building a business to sustain open source development. They discuss frontend libraries (then and now), the link between business and open source, the genesis of unpkg.com (a CDN for NPM), and the future of modules in the browser.
item.content:encoded:
Chantastic talks with Michael about his journey into open source and how he's building a business to sustain open source development. They discuss frontend libraries (then and now), the link between business and open source, the genesis of unpkg.com (a CDN for NPM), and the future of modules in the browser.

Featuring

  • Michael Jackson ‚Äî Twitter, Github, Website
  • Michael Chan ‚Äî Twitter, Github, Website

Notes & Links

  • React Router

  • Can I use modules ‚Äî Browser support for script type="module"
  • Babel on Open Collective ‚Äî Support JavaScript innovation by donating

item.title: 18: Prepack and the Future of JavaScript Performance with Nikolai Tillmann
item.description: Chantastic talks with Nikolai about Prepack ‚Äî a tool for making JavaScript code run faster. They discuss the goals and challenges before Prepack, why it makes global JavaScript faster, and how it could dramatically improve time to interactive performance in large React apps.

item.title: 16: The Good, Bad, and Ugly of Open Source with Ken Wheeler
item.description: Michael Jackson, Michael Chan, and Ken Wheeler talk Smooth Criminal, BBQ tweets, what inspires his open source work, and what he's working on as the Director of Open Source at Formidable Labs.
item.content:encoded:
Michael and Michael talk with Ken about the good, bad, and ugly of open source. Ken shares the pain and frustration he's felt as an open source developer and what keeps him coming back for more as the Director of Open Source at Formidable Labs. They talk GraphQL, Reason, React, and the best tweet Ken ever tweeted...

  • 5 things they don't want you to know about React-Apollo
  • GraphQL NYC
  • I'm fucking depressed, but it's going to be okay
  • Up and Running with Universal Components
  • Lona Tools for building design systems and using them to generate cross-platform UI code, Sketch files, and other artifacts.

item.title: 12: Coming to React with Sara Vieira
item.description: Sara Vieira is easily one of the most entertaining people we've ever had on this show. She has been working with React over the past few years and has recently been traveling around Europe and giving free workshops on React in London and at React Finland.

item.title: 11: Inside React with Sophie Alpert
item.description: Sophie Alpert is a core contributor to React and is currently the engineering manager for the React team at Facebook. She has been contributing to React for over 3 years now, making her first contributions while she was working as an engineer at Khan Academy.

item.title: 10: Codesandbox with Ives van Hoorne
item.description: Ives van Hoorne is the creator of Codesandbox; an online code editor written completely in React. Although Codesandbox is written in React, it can be used to build applications for any front-end framework.

item.title: 9: Emotion with Kye Hohenberger
item.description: Kye Hohenberger is the author of the Emotion JavaScript library, a popular choice among React developers who prefer using CSS-in-JS to traditional CSS stylesheets. In this episode we discuss his work on Emotion including where he got the initial inspiration for the project and his motivation for creating it. We also discuss the future of the project and what may be in store for the future of CSS-in-JS.
item.content:encoded:
Kye Hohenberger is the author of the Emotion JavaScript library, a popular choice among React developers who prefer using CSS-in-JS to traditional CSS stylesheets. In this episode we discuss his work on Emotion including where he got the initial inspiration for the project and his motivation for creating it. We also discuss the future of the project and what may be in store for the future of CSS-in-JS.

  • Michael Jackson ‚Äî Twitter, Github, Website

  • Emotion "next" (experimental)
  • glam
  • stylis.js

item.title: 8: React Perf Devtool with Nitin Tulswani
item.description: Nitin Tulswani is a prolific developer and the creator of react-perf-devtool, a library that helps with profiling the performance of your React components since react-addons-perf was deprecated in React 16. In this episode we discuss Nitin's approach to writing code and the motivation behind several of his open source projects.
item.content:encoded:
Nitin Tulswani is a prolific developer and the creator of react-perf-devtool, a library that helps with profiling the performance of your React components since react-addons-perf was deprecated in React 16. In this episode we discuss Nitin's approach to writing code and the motivation behind several of his open source projects.

  • Michael Jackson ‚Äî Twitter, Github, Website

Notes

  • react-perf-devtool
  • redocx, A docx renderer for React
  • terminal-in-react

item.title: 7: React and Electron with James Long
item.description: James Long is a prolific blogger and the author of several open source libraries including Prettier. He has recently started developing Actual, a budgeting app built in React and Electron. In this episode we talk about James' approach to business, as well as take a peek behind the scenes at how he works with React.
item.content:encoded:
James Long is a prolific blogger and the author of several open source libraries including Prettier. He has recently started developing Actual, a budgeting app built in React and Electron. In this episode we talk about James' approach to business, as well as take a peek behind the scenes at how he works with React.

item.title: 6: Async React with Andrew Clark
item.description: Andrew Clark is a developer on the React core team at Facebook who has been working on asynchronous rendering. In this episode we do a deep dive on some of the decisions behind the implementation of async mode in React 16 as well as talk about how applications can benefit from using it.
item.content:encoded:
Andrew Clark is a developer on the React core team at Facebook who has been working on asynchronous rendering. In this episode we do a deep dive on some of the decisions behind the implementation of async mode in React 16 as well as talk about how applications can benefit from using it.

Featuring

  • Andrew Clark ‚Äî Twitter, Github
  • Michael Jackson ‚Äî Twitter, Github, Website

Notes

  • Preview of Async Features in React 16
  • react-basic - core concepts of React
  • Update on Async Rendering in React

item.title: 5: Finite State Machines with David Khourshid
item.description: In this episode Michael Jackson talks with David Khourshid about State Machines. David is a developer on the Visual Studio Live Share team at Microsoft. Recently, he's been exploring methods of using finite state machines together with React to create predictable flows through applications that are easy to follow and test.
item.content:encoded:
In this episode Michael Jackson talks with David Khourshid about State Machines. David is a developer on the Visual Studio Live Share team at Microsoft.   • xstate
  • Statecharts: A Visual Formalism for Complex Systems

item.title: 3: The Future of React with Dan Abramov
item.description: In this episode Michael Jackson talks with Dan Abramov, author of Redux and create-react-app, about the responsibility that comes with being an influential voice for React, how future versions of React will leverage requestIdleCallback to schedule work, and the possibility of a future API for React that makes it easier to do async work.
item.content:encoded:
In this episode Michael Jackson talks with Dan Abramov, author of Redux and create-react-app, about the responsibility that comes with being an influential voice for React, how future versions of React will leverage requestIdleCallback to schedule work, and the possibility of a future API for React that makes it easier to do async work.

Featuring

  • Dan Abramov ‚Äî Twitter, Github
  • Michael Jackson ‚Äî Twitter, Github, Website

Notes

  • Beyond React 16 by Dan Abramov at JSConf Iceland
  • requestIdleCallback API

item.title: 2: Razzle, After.js, and Formik with Jared Palmer

item.title: 1: React Native for web with Nicolas Gallagher
item.description: Welcome to the inaugural episode of The React Podcast. In this episode Michael Jackson talks with Nicolas Gallagher about his project React Native for Web, the React Native API, how Twitter's new mobile website is powered by React Native for Web, and more.
item.content:encoded:
Welcome to the inaugural episode of The React Podcast. In this episode Michael Jackson talks with Nicolas Gallagher about his project React Native for Web, the React Native API, how Twitter's new mobile website is powered by React Native for Web, and more.
